Novak, Paige J.

Title:  Organohalide Respiration: Improving our Understanding for Predictable Biostimulation and Bioaugmentation

Over the next 30 years, the EPA has estimated that it will cost $250 billion to remediate approximately 350,000 contaminated sites in the US, many of which are contaminated with chlorinated pollutants. In contaminated environments bacteria of a specific kind have been identified that treat chlorinated pollutants, producing less- or non-toxic compounds as products. This proposed project will examine the various aspects of these bacteria to effectively treat these compounds in the ground, therefore lowering the cost of treatment.

In this project, laboratory-based experiments will be performed to determine, (1) how the organohalide respiring community and genes that code for the dechlorinating activity (rdh genes) change when enriched with chlorinated natural organic matter, (2) how the concentration of chloride, chlorinated natural organic matter, or chlorinated pollutants affect the numbers of organohalide respiring organisms present and the degradation rate of chlorinated natural organic matter, and finally, (3) the effectiveness of chlorinated natural organic matter as a primer for the degradation of chlorinated pollutants. This research will further understanding of organohalide respiration by investigating the rdh genes present during the dechlorination of chlorinated natural organic matter. In addition, by determining whether or not chlorinated natural organic matter can be co-degraded with a chlorinated pollutant (a polychlorinated biphenyl congener) and which rdh genes are present when this occurs, the relationship between the respiration of natural compounds versus pollutants will be established. This research has critical implications for the remediation field, ecology, and geochemical cycling by (1)providing the discovery of a pathway for the cycling of natural organic chlorine, (2) opening an avenue for further research on the evolution and regulation of rdhs, (3) pointing to a source of organisms for bioaugmentation, and a source of natural compounds for biostimulation, and (4) facilitating the development of a tool to determine the organohalide respiration potential of a soil via the mapping of the rdh genes present. The students involved in this project will be trained in a variety of laboratory methods, and the experimental and critical thinking skills developed during this study will complement their current curriculum and future careers as engineers/scientists.

por.por_cntn:
Over the next 30 years, the EPA has estimated that it will cost $250 billion to remediate approximately 350,000 contaminated sites in the US, many of which are contaminated with chlorinated organic pollutants. These pollutants have also been linked to serious health effects. Research is needed to develop ways to affordably clean up chlorinated pollutants. Fortunately, bacteria exist that are able to essentially “breathe” (or respire) chlorinated compounds, including pollutants; these bacteria are called organohalide respiring bacteria (OHRB). During the respiration process, these bacteria dechlorinate pollutants, producing less- or non-toxic compounds as products. Previous research has shown that organohalide respirers are also common in uncontaminated ecosystems, with the respiration of chlorinated natural organic matter (Cl-NOM) providing their apparent niche. Organohalide respirers found in uncontaminated environments may represent a vast untapped resource, although little is known about their abilities and what controls their activity and numbers. The major goals of this project were to obtain a better understanding of the factors that affect the concentrations of organohalide respiring bacteria in uncontaminated sediments/soils and their dechlorinating abilities. This research also sought to determine whether Cl-NOM could be used to stimulate the dechlorination of chlorinated pollutants. The activities sponsored by this grant, described below, have been successful toward reaching these major goals, resulting in two published manuscripts and two additional manuscripts to be submitted shortly. In addition, a supplement provided under this grant supported the sampling of a river in Ghana that is experiencing rapid development, including the development of aquaculture, expanding our knowledge of the chemical and genetic impacts of this development. That research will result in an additional publication.

This research showed for the first time that putative OHRB could be enriched at the interface of a hydrophobic liquid, suggesting that these bacteria are themselves hydrophobic and providing a tool for their concentration and study. It was also demonstrated for the first time that the dechlorination of chlorinated pollutants (in this case trichloroethene and tetrachlorobenzene) could be stimulated through the addition of certain fractions of Cl-NOM. This suggests that remediation could be stimulated in a similar manner. Interestingly, when mixed bacterial communities were enriched or grown on Cl-NOM, including the Cl-NOM fractions that stimulated pollutant dechlorination, the enrichment of genes coding for non-repiratory dechlorination, as well as genes used for organohalide respiration, was observed. These results highlight the importance of non-respiratory genes in dechlorination. In bioremediation, respiratory dechlorinating genes are typically the focus for stimulation; nevertheless, the detection and enrichment of non-respiratory genes at high frequencies shows that these genes may also play an important role in the global chlorine cycle and may be utilized in bioremediation. Finally, multiple locations (urban lakes, undeveloped/rural lakes, and samples from deep terrestrial mines) were surveyed for the genetic potential to dechlorinate. This potential was present in every site analyzed at gene concentrations similar to concentrations associated with nitrogen cycling genes. This suggests that dechlorination could be a common metabolic capability in terrestrial systems, an observation important in understanding chlorine and carbon cycling, ecology, and better utilizing this capability for remediation.

With respect to the supplement funding, 17 sites were sampled along the Volta River in Ghana, including sites downstream of large aquaculture facilities. A large number of chemicals were detected, including several plasticizers, atrazine, the insect repellant DEET, and several antibiotics. Several of these chemicals (notably the plasticizer triethylphosphate and the antibiotic sulfamethoxazole) dramatically increased downstream of a large aquaculture facility, along with the decline of dissolved oxygen and water clarity. The microbial community structure varied as a function of location along the river; nevertheless, the community associated with sites downstream of aquaculture shifted away from this location dependence, demonstrating the influence of other factors on community structure. Two dehalogenase genes were detected in the sediment along the entire river length, with no dependence on development or land use. 

One student supported partially on this grant earned her Ph.D. She recently accepted an offer at a consulting firm to work as an expert in remediation, demonstrating the benefits gained from working on this project and expanding their reach to the private sector and remediation practice. This project also provided valuable research experience for three undergraduate students, all of whom are now working as practicing engineers, with one having obtained his M.S. degree after working on this project and the other two planning to return to graduate school after obtaining work experience. Project results were incorporated into three courses: Introduction to Environmental Engineering, Environmental Microbiology, and Environmental Biotechnology, the later of which was taught at the University of Hawai’i, Manoa, during a sabbatical leave. Results from this research were used to describe the diversity of bacteria, communicate principles of evolution, demonstrate the value of combined culture-based and culture-independent techniques in environmental microbiology, and advance understanding of bioremediation techniques and principles.
